description: Opened in 1893, this historic Toronto landmark is the seat of Ontario's Parliament and is fully open for accessible visits. Frequent free tours are offered on weekdays throughout the year, and on the first weekend of each month. More information, including details about tours and programs, can be found at our web site. Advance bookings available online or drop by for a visit. Security screening required and government photo ID must be shown for all those 16 and up for access.

reviews.title: A fascinating and inspiring visit
text: We had an incredible experience visiting the "Ontario Legislative Building". My son, who’s studying political science and international relations, was eager to explore the inside, and we were in luck—a guided tour was being offered by the assembly. It was an amazing opportunity, and the tour itself was fascinating.

One of the highlights was being able to step into the legislative chamber—such a unique and memorable experience! We also learned about the inspiring "Grandfather Teachings", which added a deeper cultural perspective to our visit.

The staff were incredibly kind and welcoming, which made the entire experience even more enjoyable. Overall, it was a perfect outing, and I highly recommend it to anyone interested in history, politics, or just exploring a beautiful part of Ontario.

reviews.title: Beautiful Building
text: When traveling in the US, we make an effort to visit statehouses.  So while in Toronto our family thought we should tour the Ontario Legislative Building if we could

The one hour indoor/outdoor tour was free, with easy online registration.  Our being at 3 PM, so the building seemed less busy than might be expected.  Tour was informative, with a great guide, and the building and grounds are quite impressive.
Check-in was easy, despite being the usual security that we, unfortunately, have to often do these days.

reviews.title: Historic hall
text: I particularly like this building and area. The grounds are full of statues of major Toronto historical figures. Manicured gardens surround the building

reviews.title: Highly Recommend
text: This is a lovely looking building that offers free tours every 30 minutes until around 5 PM.
The front steps of the building is also featured in a Rush band album called Moving Pictures, of course my wife who’s the biggest Rush fan ever had to inform me of this.
Anyway, we took the free tour which was guided and we enjoyed it. Photos are allowed which we appreciated. They take you through several rooms of the building explaining each one.

After the tour, you’re free to look around the lobby area which has some interesting historical items and there’s a gift shop as well. It’s a nice interesting tour and it’s free so I’d highly recommend checking this place out.

reviews.title: Nice building
text: I was not able to get in as it was closed for some reason. However, the exterior was still admirable, and it was a satisfying quick stop while my visit of the University of Toronto.

reviews.title: Guided tour only
text: We visited the building on June 26. The only way you can visit the Legislative Building is on a guided tour. You must pass a security check and present official ID. The tour takes about 30-45 minutes depending on the number of questions. The building is not that impressive. Nick our guide was very informative and had answers to all our questions.

reviews.title: An ok stop
text: It was pretty but kind of underwhelming. The university buildings around are nice, and the round drive/roads are cool.

reviews.title: Doors Open, a lot to see, did not disappoint
text: This was first on our list for day 1 of Doors Open Toronto weekend (May 28-29) and it did not disappoint.  The Ontario Legislative Building has an impressive facade--we cannot help but spend a few minutes outside and take photos of it and some of the monuments and memorials in Queen's Park. Building entrance is on the south side where everyone has to go through airport-style screening complete with walk-through metal detector and x-ray scanner. Expect visible security presence, tour route directional signs and cordoned off areas.

The self-guided tour took us from the first floor of the east wing, up the stairs to the second floor then inside the iconic Legislative Chamber and the Lieutenant Governor's Suite and finally to the west wing. There was definitely a lot to see and staff was on hand to answer any questions from visitors. Photography is allowed.
Some of the things to see inside the Legislative Building:
The east wing's elegant oak floors and panels versus the newer west wing's cold marble floors and pillars - both are stunning but I like wood better
Portraits of Ontario Premiers - current Premier Doug Ford will only get his after he is out of office
Class pictures of all Ontario MPPs since the 1st Parliament
Legislative Chamber -mostly off-limits - visitors can only look at the Chamber from inside the main doors

Lieutenant Governor's Suite - lovely, elegantly furnished room - staff told us the carpet is entirely in one piece and had to be brought in through the windows; staircase full of portraits reminded me of museums
Ontario coat of arms on the stained glass ceiling in the west wing

We spent about an hour inside the building and we did not even look at everything. From the east wing, the tour ends at the lobby right in front of the cordoned off grand staircase. Exit is at the front doors directly facing University Ave.
Note: FREE guided tours are offered year-round. Advance registration required.

reviews.title: Excellent free tour - impressive building
text: We booked a free tour online around 1 hour ahead. There was loads of availability, with 15 spaces per 30 minute  tour. Staff were really friendly. You have to clear security and bring ID with you. Our tour guide was excellent, very knowledgeable.  It was an excellent activity on a rainy morning in Toronto. The building itself is very impressive inside and out and we learned a great deal about the traditions and process of law making in Ontario.

reviews.title: Wish it was open
text: Unfortunately, I was only able to see it from the outside, because the building was closed due to Labor day. I can say for sure that it looks great (again) from the outside and I can't wait to see it when I come back to Toronto.

reviews.title: The Pink Palace
text: The building known as Queens Park (QP) houses the Legislative Assembly of Ontario - our parliament -created by the British North America Act of 1867 which turned Upper Canada into Ontario and Lower Canada into Quebec, among other things. Canada counts 1867 as her birthday.
The Upper Canada Assembly originally met in a building on Parliament Street, but it was burned by the Americans in the war of 1812.
Queens Park was granted to the Province by the City of Toronto in 1880, and the parliament building was consructed of pink limestone, modelled after the Palace of Westminster in London.

Unlike Westminster, QP has only one chamber for the Members, but the arraangement is similar, with seats for the government on one side and the opposition on the other. There is a Speaker's throne, pages, clerks and the Master at Arms. QP employs a private police force to take care of security.
Behind the Members' areas there are "back rooms" for meetings. Above the main chamber ther are galleries for the public, Members' guests and the Press/media.

To attend a meeting of the legislature the public must sign in at the security desk and surrender all their belongings except for a wallet: no cell phones, no newspapers, nothing is allowed in the public gallery. The public is not permitted to make any noise or any kind of applause.
For visitors to the Members' Gallery, they must be signed in by their MPP and go thorugh a different security section. Again cell phones and large bags must be stored, but handbags are permitted.
Tours of the building are conducted. There is a gift shop on the main floor.
On the upper floors there are many offices for the members and their staff. Also the Queen's representative, the Lieutenant Governor, has a suite of rooms on the west side.

There is a nice, cheap cafeteria in the basement, and visitors can get a security pass just to this area.The closest transit stop is Queens Park on subway Line 1 at College Street. There is also a streetcar service on College/Carleton, number 506.
Because the building was constructed before air conditioning, its thick walls and through ventilation make it quite comfortable during the summer months.
The Pink Palace is surrounded by beautiful public gardens, which are commonly used for political demonstrations and other events.
I have not personally taken the tour, but I have participated in the other activities I have mentioned.

reviews.title: Great for Toronto / Ontario history
text: I went for the free lunchtime tour in the building. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and she made it quite interesting with the older pictures of the city and the building. The interior decor and just knowing that you have seen a spot where political decisions are made was quite cool.

reviews.title: Nice free tour
text: We took the inside/outside tour and it was very nice.  It was great to get a bit of history, too.  Too bad the park behind it was under major construction

reviews.title: One of my favourite buildings
text: The home of the Ontario government is well worth a visit. Some remarkable woodwork and very interesting memorabilia throughout the building. Second floor offices are amazing and sitting in the visitor’s gallery to watch the crazy Question Period is entertaining.

reviews.title: Lovely FREE tour
text: We visited the Ontario Legislative Building to have a look at the outside architecture and grounds, which were lovely.

An additional surprise was the free guided half hour tour of the main chamber and corridors of the building.  Our guide was really informative and explained the history of the regional government as well as how it works today.
We found it really interesting and it was really nice to go inside and have a look around.

reviews.title: Free and interesting
text: There is a very short 30 minute tour that is cool.  Don’t plan a whole weekend trip just to see it but it was an awesome way to spend an hour.   The guide was great.

reviews.title: Beautiful Building!
text: We decided to go check out this building, because of the "Rush" Album cover! I know a totally American tourist thing to do! But we discover the beautiful Queens Park and The Legislative building is way more than the album cover! What a beautiful stone building! What amazing craftsmanship went into it! A True Gem!

reviews.title: Family roadtrip
text: This was a stop on our roadtrip photo scavenger hunt, trying to take pictures of several of the statues around the building.  There are lots of very helpful police on every side who are nice enough to pose for a scavenger hunt selfie or two.

reviews.title: new government
text: we Ontarians have a new tory provincial government with a majority of seats! High hopes  from a lot of residents to make a better province in the future, we'll wait and see in these 4 years term.

reviews.title: Grand, monumental building
text: The seat of the Government of Ontario is located in this red stone, grand building. It is impressive both outside and in. Even if you only have a few minutes, it’s worth walking and  and going up the grand staircase. Staring at you on the walls are the past Premiers of the Province.

reviews.title: Boring single parliament building.
text: Can not think of a more boring government building to visit.
But it is a popular spot for protesters.

reviews.title: Ontario Legislative Building, Toronto, Ontario, Canada
text: Must visit to appreciate this building.  Offers tours every half hour.  No need to reserve just show up and book on the spot. Read up on the history of this great building!

reviews.title: my first time here
text: I went here with my female partner (from HK) and my Asian grandson.He was interested in the junior school tour program and easter egg hunt to learn about parliment.We joined the kids tour of the facility and I was impressed with the archtecture of the building and the history behind.I am glad I went there although a lot of walking.parking was close buy and entry was free.I recommend PH

reviews.title: Nice tours
text: The tours start at each hour. The stuff there is very friendly and provide many information. The entrance is free, but you have to show them your id card. If there is a meeting that is taking place in the main room, you won't be able to see it, together with the scepter.

reviews.title: Visit to the Premier's office!
text: Visited the building during the Open Doors (when entry is free to a lot of places in Toronto)
The place is beautiful, well kept. Lots of history and paintings.
Though couldn't see house in session, i have heard you are allowed to visit when it is.
they also have some educative tours/programs for children. So check that out.

reviews.title: Walking with the Giants
text: Our tour of Ontario's legislative building was very historical, well done. Staff were very helpful. We met Christine Elliot, Doug Ford too. Ministers and the Premier walking about. Great experience getting to visit Our House..The Peoples House

reviews.title: Well worth the visit
text: We got a tour around the Legislative Assembly of Ontario and its well worth your time if you can arrange it, very informative, saw the morning parade and lots other items to see on the tour very informative, the art work was great and the stained glass ceilings are fabulous.

reviews.title: Ontario Legislative Building
text: It is an impressive building and the stone work was awesome to see.  It was closed when we were there but would have loved to see the inside.

reviews.title: Beautiful Building
text: This is a beautiful building that stands at the head of University Avenue in the University of Toronto area. This red sandstone building is the seat of the Ontario government. There are tour offered of the grounds and of the inside. The inside of the building is beautiful with lots of wood being used. The lawns and gardens around the building are well kept. Being a legislative building there are restrictions on entrance so best to take a tour. It is also possible to view the legislature while it is sitting by obtaining seats in the visitors' gallery.

reviews.title: Waste of time
text: There is really nothing going on at this place. Most areas are restricted. It would be better if it wasn't inhabited by Doug "the thumb" Ford and his conservative flunkies.

reviews.title: government building with great architecture
text: Again, a really cool building if you're into architecture and want to be able to go through, walking the grounds and hanging out with a coffee is pretty nice too

reviews.title: Wish We Could Have Entered the Building
text: We walked all around the beautiful grounds, but alas we were there on a Saturday and couldn't enter the building.

reviews.title: Interesting history
text: We were like many who could not initially gain access as we had no photo ID so had to come back later. Tours are free so you cannot complain and last about half an hour. You are restricted on where you can go but on the day we visited there was no sitting so we were lucky to go into the actual chamber.
Plenty of information was given about the parliamentary process and the history of the building as we moved around, explaining about the new and old parts of the building, pre & post fire.
Definitely worth a visit

reviews.title: Nice
text: Great historic building in Toronto. Nice outdoor space as well. Unfortunately, no tours on the weekend.

reviews.title: Beautiful Old Building
text: We had a free guided tour and it was very interesting to find out a lot of facts about how Toronto came about and how the Provincial government works. Short visit but very informative. The statues dotted around outside are interesting too.  Thank goodness they haven't taken down the statue of John A. McDonalds's statue, our first Prime Minister!

reviews.title: Interesting and it's Free
text: I stumbled across the building by accident, and when I went inside learned that free tours were on offer. You do need photo ID to enter, and to granted access by the Constable.
It's a very impressive building inside, but you only visit a few rooms on the tour. You are allowed to take pictures and use a flash.

reviews.title: Boring
text: Dont waist your time, its an hour of my life ill never get back. The walk alone was not worth the steps it took to get to the doors

reviews.title: Old Glory Still in Fashion.
text: Same era and style as Toronto Old City Hall and the Parliament Buildings. Heritage that can not be replaced.

reviews.title: Historic building, good information about government decision making process
text: You can book a visit and also without booking, attend a question period in the House. Be sure to check whether the House is in session and the time of the question period. There are many plaques and items helping you understand the history and current process better.

reviews.title: Nothing Special
text: Impressed that how the main road leading up to the building goes from a built up area and into an open space, the building itself is nothing special as there are far better ones.
